<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Beyoncé skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Beyoncé</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">For the album, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beyonc%C3%A9_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beyoncé (album) (page does not exist)">Beyoncé (album)</a>.</div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-blp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-blp (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-blp</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_person&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox person (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox person</a>
</p><p><b>Beyoncé Giselle Knowles-Carter</b>,<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mononymous_person&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mononymous person (page does not exist)">simply known as</a> <b>Beyoncé</b>, (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Respell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Respell (page does not exist)">Template:Respell</a>) (born September 4, 1981)<sup id="cite_ref-Born_to_be_a_Star_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Born_to_be_a_Star-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> is an American recording artist and actress. Born and raised in <a href="/wiki/Houston" title="Houston">Houston</a>, Texas, she performed in various singing and dancing competitions as a child, and rose to fame in the late 1990s as lead singer of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Contemporary_R%26B&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Contemporary R&amp;B (page does not exist)">R&amp;B</a> girl-group <a href="/wiki/Destiny%27s_Child" title="Destiny's Child">Destiny's Child</a>. Managed by her father <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mathew_Knowles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mathew Knowles (page does not exist)">Mathew Knowles</a>, the group became one of the world's <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_best-selling_girl_groups&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of best-selling girl groups (page does not exist)">best-selling girl groups</a> of all time. Their hiatus saw the release of Beyoncé's debut album, <i><a href="/wiki/Dangerously_in_Love" title="Dangerously in Love">Dangerously in Love</a></i> (2003), which established her as a viable solo artist worldwide; it sold 11&#160;million copies, earned five <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">Grammy Awards</a> and featured the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Billboard_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Billboard (magazine) (page does not exist)">Billboard</a></i> number-one singles "<a href="/wiki/Crazy_in_Love_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)" title="Crazy in Love (Beyoncé song)">Crazy in Love</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Baby_Boy_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)" title="Baby Boy (Beyoncé song)">Baby Boy</a>".
</p><p>Following the disbandment of Destiny's Child in 2005, she released her second solo album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=B%27Day&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="B'Day (page does not exist)">B'Day</a></i> (2006), which contained hits "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Irreplaceable&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Irreplaceable (page does not exist)">Irreplaceable</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Beautiful_Liar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beautiful Liar (page does not exist)">Beautiful Liar</a>". Beyoncé also ventured into acting, with a <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award" title="Golden Globe Award">Golden Globe</a>-nominated performance in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dreamgirls_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dreamgirls (film) (page does not exist)">Dreamgirls</a></i> (2006), and starring roles in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Pink_Panther_(2006_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Pink Panther (2006 film) (page does not exist)">The Pink Panther</a></i> (2006) and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Obsessed_(2009_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Obsessed (2009 film) (page does not exist)">Obsessed</a></i> (2009). Her marriage to rapper <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a> and portrayal of <a href="/wiki/Etta_James" title="Etta James">Etta James</a> in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cadillac_Records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cadillac Records (page does not exist)">Cadillac Records</a></i> (2008) influenced her third album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am..._Sasha_Fierce&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am... Sasha Fierce (page does not exist)">I Am... Sasha Fierce</a></i> (2008), which saw the birth of her alter-ego Sasha Fierce and earned a record-setting <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Award records (page does not exist)">six Grammy Awards</a> in 2010, including <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Song_of_the_Year" title="Grammy Award for Song of the Year">Song of the Year</a> for "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Single_Ladies_(Put_a_Ring_on_It)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It) (page does not exist)">Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)</a>". Beyoncé took a hiatus from music in 2010 and took over management of her career; <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=4_(Beyonc%C3%A9_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="4 (Beyoncé album) (page does not exist)">4</a></i> (2011) was subsequently mellower in tone, exploring 1970s <a href="/wiki/Funk" title="Funk">funk</a>, 1980s <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop</a> and 1990s <a href="/wiki/Soul_music" title="Soul music">soul</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> Her fifth album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beyonc%C3%A9_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beyoncé (album) (page does not exist)">Beyoncé</a></i> (2013), was critically acclaimed and was distinguished from previous releases by its experimental production and exploration of darker themes. 
</p><p>A self-described "modern-day <a href="/wiki/Feminism" title="Feminism">feminist</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> Beyoncé's songs are often characterized by themes of love, relationships and monogamy, as well as female sexuality and empowerment. On stage, her dynamic, highly-choreographed performances have led to critics hailing her as one of the best entertainers in contemporary popular music. Throughout a career spanning 16 years, she has won 17 Grammy Awards and sold over 118&#160;million records as a solo artist<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> and 60&#160;million with Destiny's Child,<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> making her one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">best-selling music artists</a> of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-2012CareerSales_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2012CareerSales-8">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hamlin_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hamlin-9">[9]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recording_Industry_Association_of_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recording Industry Association of America (page does not exist)">Recording Industry Association of America</a> recognized Beyoncé as the Top Certified Artist in America during the 2000s decade.<sup id="cite_ref-RIAADecade1_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RIAADecade1-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RIAADecade2_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RIAADecade2-11">[11]</a></sup> In 2009, <i>Billboard</i> named her the Top Radio Songs Artist of the Decade,<sup id="cite_ref-RadioSongsArtist_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RadioSongsArtist-12">[12]</a></sup> the Top Female Artist of the 2000s and their Artist of the Millennium in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> In 2013, she was also included in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_magazine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time magazine (page does not exist)">Time</a></i> magazine's list of the 100 most influential people in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span></h2>
<p>Beyoncé Giselle Knowles was born in Houston to <a href="/wiki/Xerox" title="Xerox">Xerox</a> sales manager <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mathew_Knowles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mathew Knowles (page does not exist)">Mathew Knowles</a> and hairdresser/salon owner <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tina_Knowles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tina Knowles (page does not exist)">Celestine Ann "Tina" Beyincé</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> Mathew is of African descent while Tina, a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Louisiana_Creole_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Louisiana Creole people (page does not exist)">Louisiana Creole</a>, has African, French, and Native American ancestry.<sup id="cite_ref-FOX_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOX-18">[18]</a></sup> Through her mother, Beyoncé is a descendant of Acadian leader <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joseph_Broussard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joseph Broussard (page does not exist)">Joseph Broussard</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> Beyoncé's name is a tribute to her mother's maiden name.<sup id="cite_ref-FOX_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOX-18">[18]</a></sup> Beyoncé's younger sister <a href="/wiki/Solange_Knowles" title="Solange Knowles">Solange</a> is also a recording artist and actress.<sup id="cite_ref-sheridan2011_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sheridan2011-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé was educated at St. Mary's Elementary School in <a href="/wiki/Fredericksburg,_Texas" title="Fredericksburg, Texas">Fredericksburg, Texas</a>, where she enrolled in dance classes. Her singing talent was discovered when dance instructor Darlette Johnson began humming a song and she finished it, hitting the high-pitched notes.<sup id="cite_ref-danceclasses_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-danceclasses-21">[21]</a></sup> Beyoncé's interest in music and performing continued after winning a school talent show aged seven, singing <a href="/wiki/John_Lennon" title="John Lennon">John Lennon</a>'s "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Imagine_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Imagine (song) (page does not exist)">Imagine</a>" to beat 15 and 16-year-olds.<sup id="cite_ref-Biography_Today_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Biography_Today-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-People_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-People-23">[23]</a></sup> In fall of 1990, Beyoncé enrolled in Parker Elementary School, a music <a href="/wiki/Magnet_school" title="Magnet school">magnet school</a> in Houston, where she would perform with the school's choir.<sup id="cite_ref-contactbio_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-contactbio-24">[24]</a></sup> She also attended the <a href="/wiki/High_School_for_the_Performing_and_Visual_Arts" title="High School for the Performing and Visual Arts">High School for the Performing and Visual Arts</a><sup id="cite_ref-contactbio_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-contactbio-24">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> and later <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alief_Elsik_High_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alief Elsik High School (page does not exist)">Alief Elsik High School</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOX_18-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOX-18">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> Beyoncé was also a member of the choir at St. John's United Methodist Church as a <a href="/wiki/Solo_(music)" title="Solo (music)">soloist</a> for two years.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>Aged eight, Beyoncé and childhood friend <a href="/wiki/Kelly_Rowland" title="Kelly Rowland">Kelly Rowland</a> met <a href="/wiki/LaTavia_Roberson" title="LaTavia Roberson">LaTavia Roberson</a> while in an audition for an all-girl entertainment group.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup> They were placed into a group with three other girls as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Girl%27s_Tyme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Girl's Tyme (page does not exist)">Girl's Tyme</a>, and rapped and danced on the talent show circuit in Houston.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> After seeing the group, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Contemporary_R%26B&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Contemporary R&amp;B (page does not exist)">R&amp;B</a> producer Arne Frager brought them to his <a href="/wiki/Northern_California" title="Northern California">Northern California</a> studio and placed them in <i><a href="/wiki/Star_Search" title="Star Search">Star Search</a></i>, the largest talent show on national TV at the time. Girl's Tyme failed to win, and Beyoncé later said the song they performed was not good.<sup id="cite_ref-Farley_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Farley-30">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-J.R._31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-J.R.-31">[31]</a></sup> In 1995 Beyoncé's father resigned from his job to manage the group.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> The move reduced Beyoncé's family's income by half, and her parents were forced to move into separated apartments.<sup id="cite_ref-FOX_18-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOX-18">[18]</a></sup> Mathew cut the original line-up to four and the group continued performing as an opening act for other established R&amp;B girl groups.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup> The girls auditioned before record labels and were finally signed to <a href="/wiki/Elektra_Records" title="Elektra Records">Elektra Records</a>, moving to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_record_labels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atlanta record labels (page does not exist)">Atlanta Records</a> briefly to work on their first recording, only to be cut by the company.<sup id="cite_ref-FOX_18-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOX-18">[18]</a></sup> This put further strain on the family, and Beyoncé's parents <a href="/wiki/Legal_separation" title="Legal separation">separated</a>. On October 5, 1995, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dwayne_Wiggins&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dwayne Wiggins (page does not exist)">Dwayne Wiggins</a>'s Grass Roots Entertainment signed the group. In 1996, the girls began recording their debut album under an agreement with Sony Music, the Knowles family reunited, and shortly after, the group got a contract with <a href="/wiki/Columbia_Records" title="Columbia Records">Columbia Records</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Biography_Today_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Biography_Today-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1997.E2.80.932001:_Destiny.27s_Child">1997–2001: Destiny's Child</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Destiny%27s_Child_Tour.jpg" title="File:Destiny's Child Tour.jpg">File:Destiny's Child Tour.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Destiny's Child performing "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Say_My_Name&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Say My Name (page does not exist)">Say My Name</a>", a single that garnered critical and commercial success, along with two Grammy Awards</div></div></div>
<p>The group changed their name to Destiny's Child in 1996, based on a passage in the <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Isaiah" title="Book of Isaiah">Book of Isaiah</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> In 1997, Destiny's Child released their major label debut song "Killing Time" on the soundtrack to the 1997 film, <i><a href="/wiki/Men_in_Black_(film)" title="Men in Black (film)">Men in Black</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-J.R._31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-J.R.-31">[31]</a></sup> The following year, the group released their <a href="/w/index.php?title=Destiny%27s_Child_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Destiny's Child (album) (page does not exist)">self-titled debut album</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Farley_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Farley-30">[30]</a></sup> scoring their first major hit "<a href="/w/index.php?title=No,_No,_No_(Destiny%27s_Child_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="No, No, No (Destiny's Child song) (page does not exist)">No, No, No</a>". The album established the group as a viable act in the music industry, with moderate sales and winning the group three Soul Train Lady of Soul Awards for Best R&amp;B/Soul Album of the Year, Best R&amp;B/Soul or Rap New Artist, and Best R&amp;B/Soul Single for "No, No, No".<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup> The group released their multi-platinum second album <i><a href="/wiki/The_Writing%27s_on_the_Wall" title="The Writing's on the Wall">The Writing's on the Wall</a></i> in 1999. The record features some of the group's most widely known songs such as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Bills,_Bills,_Bills&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bills, Bills, Bills (page does not exist)">Bills, Bills, Bills</a>," the group's first number-one single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Jumpin%27_Jumpin%27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jumpin' Jumpin' (page does not exist)">Jumpin' Jumpin'</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Say_My_Name&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Say My Name (page does not exist)">Say My Name</a>", which became their most successful song at the time, and would remain one of their signature songs. "Say My Name" won the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_R%26B_Performance_by_a_Duo_or_Group_with_Vocals" title="Grammy Award for Best R&amp;B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals">Best R&amp;B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_R%26B_Song" title="Grammy Award for Best R&amp;B Song">Best R&amp;B Song</a> at the <a href="/wiki/43rd_Annual_Grammy_Awards" title="43rd Annual Grammy Awards">43rd Annual Grammy Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup> <i>The Writing's on the Wall</i> sold more than eight million copies worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-Farley_30-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Farley-30">[30]</a></sup> During this time, Beyoncé recorded a duet with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marc_Nelson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marc Nelson (page does not exist)">Marc Nelson</a>, an original member of <a href="/wiki/Boyz_II_Men" title="Boyz II Men">Boyz II Men</a>, on the song "After All Is Said and Done" for the soundtrack to the 1999 film, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Best_Man_(1999_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Best Man (1999 film) (page does not exist)">The Best Man</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/LeToya_Luckett" title="LeToya Luckett">LeToya Luckett</a> and Roberson became unhappy with Mathew's managing of the band and eventually were replaced by <a href="/wiki/Farrah_Franklin" title="Farrah Franklin">Farrah Franklin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Michelle_Williams_(singer)" title="Michelle Williams (singer)">Michelle Williams</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup> Beyoncé experienced <a href="/wiki/Depression_(mood)" title="Depression (mood)">depression</a> following the split with Luckett and Roberson after being publicly blamed by the media, critics, and blogs for its cause.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> Her long-standing boyfriend left her at this time.<sup id="cite_ref-Depression_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Depression-36">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> The depression was so severe it lasted for a couple of years, during which she occasionally kept herself in her bedroom for days and refused to eat anything.<sup id="cite_ref-Depression_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Depression-36">[36]</a></sup> Beyoncé stated that she struggled to speak about her depression because Destiny's Child had just won their first <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">Grammy Award</a> and she feared no one would take her seriously.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> Beyoncé would later speak of her mother as the person who helped her fight it.<sup id="cite_ref-Depression_36-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Depression-36">[36]</a></sup> Franklin was dismissed, leaving just Beyoncé, Rowland, and Williams.<sup id="cite_ref-DunnDate_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DunnDate-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>The remaining band members recorded "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Independent_Women_Part_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Independent Women Part I (page does not exist)">Independent Women Part&#160;I</a>", which appeared on the soundtrack to the 2000 film, <i><a href="/wiki/Charlie%27s_Angels_(film)" title="Charlie's Angels (film)">Charlie's Angels</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup> It became their best-charting single, topping the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a> chart for eleven consecutive weeks.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup> In early 2001, while Destiny's Child was completing their third album, Beyoncé landed a major role in the MTV made-for-television film, <i><a href="/wiki/Carmen:_A_Hip_Hopera" title="Carmen: A Hip Hopera">Carmen: A Hip Hopera</a></i>, starring alongside American actor <a href="/wiki/Mekhi_Phifer" title="Mekhi Phifer">Mekhi Phifer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-carmen_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-carmen-40">[40]</a></sup> Set in <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, the film is a modern interpretation of the 19th century opera <i><a href="/wiki/Carmen" title="Carmen">Carmen</a></i> by French composer <a href="/wiki/Georges_Bizet" title="Georges Bizet">Georges Bizet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-carmen_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-carmen-40">[40]</a></sup> When the third album <i><a href="/wiki/Survivor_(Destiny%27s_Child_album)" title="Survivor (Destiny's Child album)">Survivor</a></i> was released in May 2001, Luckett and Roberson filed a lawsuit claiming that the songs were aimed at them.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup> The album debuted at number one on the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200"><i>Billboard</i> 200</a>, with first-week sales of 663,000 copies sold.<sup id="cite_ref-Martens3_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Martens3-41">[41]</a></sup> The album spawned other number-one hits, "<a href="/wiki/Bootylicious" title="Bootylicious">Bootylicious</a>" and the title track, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Survivor_(Destiny%27s_Child_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Survivor (Destiny's Child song) (page does not exist)">Survivor</a>", the latter of which earned the group a Grammy Award for Best R&amp;B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> After releasing their holiday album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=8_Days_of_Christmas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="8 Days of Christmas (page does not exist)">8&#160;Days of Christmas</a></i> in October 2001, the group announced a hiatus to further pursue solo careers.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2002.E2.80.9307:_Dangerously_in_Love.2C_B.27Day.2C_and_Dreamgirls">2002–07: <i>Dangerously in Love</i>, <i>B'Day</i>, and <i>Dreamgirls</i></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beyonce_Baby_Boy_Dancing.jpg" title="File:Beyonce Baby Boy Dancing.jpg">File:Beyonce Baby Boy Dancing.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Beyoncé performing "<a href="/wiki/Baby_Boy_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)" title="Baby Boy (Beyoncé song)">Baby Boy</a>", which spent nine consecutive weeks at number one on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a> chart<sup id="cite_ref-BabyBoy1_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BabyBoy1-43">[43]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In July 2002, Beyoncé continued her acting career playing <a href="/wiki/Foxxy_Cleopatra" title="Foxxy Cleopatra" class="mw-redirect">Foxxy Cleopatra</a> alongside <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mike_Myers_(actor)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mike Myers (actor) (page does not exist)">Mike Myers</a> in the comedy film, <i><a href="/wiki/Austin_Powers_in_Goldmember" title="Austin Powers in Goldmember">Austin Powers in Goldmember</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> which spent its first weekend atop the US box office and grossed $73&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> Beyoncé released "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Work_It_Out_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Work It Out (Beyoncé song) (page does not exist)">Work It Out</a>" as the lead single from its soundtrack album which entered the top ten in the UK, Norway, and Belgium.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> In 2003, Beyoncé starred opposite <a href="/wiki/Cuba_Gooding,_Jr." title="Cuba Gooding, Jr.">Cuba Gooding,&#160;Jr.</a>, in the musical comedy <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Fighting_Temptations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Fighting Temptations (page does not exist)">The Fighting Temptations</a></i> as Lilly, a single mother whom Gooding's character falls in love with.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> The film received mixed reviews from critics but grossed $30&#160;million in US.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> Beyoncé released "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fighting_Temptation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fighting Temptation (page does not exist)">Fighting Temptation</a>" as the lead single from the film's soundtrack album, with <a href="/wiki/Missy_Elliott" title="Missy Elliott">Missy Elliott</a>, <a href="/wiki/MC_Lyte" title="MC Lyte">MC Lyte</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Free_(rapper)" title="Free (rapper)">Free</a> which was also used to promote the film.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> Another of Beyoncé's contributions to the soundtrack, "Summertime", fared better on the US charts.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé's first solo recording was a feature on <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a>'s "<a href="/w/index.php?title=%2703_Bonnie_%26_Clyde&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="'03 Bonnie &amp; Clyde (page does not exist)">'03 Bonnie &amp; Clyde</a>" that was released in October 2002, peaking at number four on the U.S. <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 chart.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> Her first solo album <i><a href="/wiki/Dangerously_in_Love" title="Dangerously in Love">Dangerously in Love</a></i> was released on June 24, 2003, after Michelle Williams and Kelly Rowland had released their solo efforts.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> The album sold 317,000 copies in its first week and debuted atop the <i>Billboard</i> 200.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a> it remains Beyoncé's best-selling album, with 11&#160;million copies sold worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> Beyoncé was the first artist in twenty years and first woman in chart history to have both an album and single debut on top of the UK and US charts at the same time.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> The album's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lead_single&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lead single (page does not exist)">lead single</a>, "Crazy in Love", featuring Jay-Z, became Beyoncé's first number-one single as a solo artist in the US.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> The single "<a href="/wiki/Baby_Boy_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)" title="Baby Boy (Beyoncé song)">Baby Boy</a>" also reached number one,<sup id="cite_ref-BabyBoy1_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BabyBoy1-43">[43]</a></sup> and singles, "<a href="/wiki/Me,_Myself_and_I_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)" title="Me, Myself and I (Beyoncé song)">Me, Myself and I</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Naughty_Girl_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Naughty Girl (Beyoncé song) (page does not exist)">Naughty Girl</a>", both reached the top-five.<sup id="cite_ref-beyoncehot100_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beyoncehot100-59">[59]</a></sup> The album earned Beyoncé a then record-tying five awards at the <a href="/wiki/46th_Annual_Grammy_Awards" title="46th Annual Grammy Awards">46th Annual Grammy Awards</a>; <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Contemporary_R%26B_Album" title="Grammy Award for Best Contemporary R&amp;B Album">Best Contemporary R&amp;B Album</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Female_R%26B_Vocal_Performance" title="Grammy Award for Best Female R&amp;B Vocal Performance">Best Female R&amp;B Vocal Performance</a> for "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Dangerously_in_Love_2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dangerously in Love 2 (page does not exist)">Dangerously in Love&#160;2</a>", Best R&amp;B Song and <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Rap/Sung_Collaboration" title="Grammy Award for Best Rap/Sung Collaboration">Best Rap/Sung Collaboration</a> for "Crazy in Love", and <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_R%26B_Performance_by_a_Duo_or_Group_with_Vocals" title="Grammy Award for Best R&amp;B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals">Best R&amp;B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals</a> for "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Closer_I_Get_to_You&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Closer I Get to You (page does not exist)">The Closer I Get to You</a>" with <a href="/wiki/Luther_Vandross" title="Luther Vandross">Luther Vandross</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2004_Grammys_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2004_Grammys-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2003, she embarked on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dangerously_in_Love_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dangerously in Love Tour (page does not exist)">Dangerously in Love Tour</a> in Europe and later toured alongside Missy Elliott and <a href="/wiki/Alicia_Keys" title="Alicia Keys">Alicia Keys</a> for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Verizon_Ladies_First_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Verizon Ladies First Tour (page does not exist)">Verizon Ladies First Tour</a> in North America.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> On February 1, 2004, Beyoncé performed the <a href="/wiki/The_Star-Spangled_Banner" title="The Star-Spangled Banner">American national anthem</a> at <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVIII" title="Super Bowl XXXVIII">Super Bowl XXXVIII</a>, at the <a href="/wiki/Reliant_Stadium" title="Reliant Stadium">Reliant Stadium</a> in Houston, Texas.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> After the release of <i>Dangerously in Love</i>, Beyoncé had planned to produce a follow-up album using several of the left-over tracks.<sup id="cite_ref-JPatel_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JPatel-63">[63]</a></sup> However, this was put on hold so she could concentrate on recording <i><a href="/wiki/Destiny_Fulfilled" title="Destiny Fulfilled">Destiny Fulfilled</a></i>, the final studio album by Destiny's Child.<sup id="cite_ref-JPatel_63-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JPatel-63">[63]</a></sup> Released on November 15, 2004, in the US<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> and peaking at number two on the <i>Billboard</i> 200,<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-riaadestinyschild_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-riaadestinyschild-66">[66]</a></sup> <i>Destiny Fulfilled</i> included the singles "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Lose_My_Breath&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lose My Breath (page does not exist)">Lose My Breath</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Soldier_(Destiny%27s_Child_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soldier (Destiny's Child song) (page does not exist)">Soldier</a>", which reached the top five on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 chart.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> Destiny's Child embarked on a worldwide concert tour, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Destiny_Fulfilled..._and_Lovin%27_It&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Destiny Fulfilled... and Lovin' It (page does not exist)">Destiny Fulfilled... and Lovin' It</a> and during the last stop of their European tour, in <a href="/wiki/Barcelona" title="Barcelona">Barcelona</a> on June 11, 2005, Rowland announced that Destiny's Child would disband following the North American leg of the tour.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> The group released their first <a href="/wiki/Compilation_album" title="Compilation album">compilation album</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Number_1%27s_(Destiny%27s_Child_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Number 1's (Destiny's Child album) (page does not exist)">Number&#160;1's</a></i> on October 25, 2005, in the US<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> and accepted a star on the <a href="/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame" title="Hollywood Walk of Fame">Hollywood Walk of Fame</a> in March 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beyonce,_May_2007.jpg" title="File:Beyonce, May 2007.jpg">File:Beyonce, May 2007.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Beyoncé performing during <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beyonc%C3%A9_Experience&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beyoncé Experience (page does not exist)">The Beyoncé Experience</a> concert tour in May 2007</div></div></div>
<p>Beyoncé's second solo album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=B%27Day&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="B'Day (page does not exist)">B'Day</a></i> was released on September 5, 2006, in the US, to coincide with her twenty-fifth birthday.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> It sold 541,000 copies in its first week and debuted atop the <i>Billboard</i> 200, becoming Beyoncé's second consecutive number-one album in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> The album's lead single was "<a href="/w/index.php?title=D%C3%A9j%C3%A0_Vu_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Déjà Vu (Beyoncé song) (page does not exist)">Déjà Vu</a>", which featured Jay-Z.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> The second international single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Irreplaceable&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Irreplaceable (page does not exist)">Irreplaceable</a>" was a commercial success worldwide, reaching number one in Australia, Hungary, Ireland, and New Zealand.<sup id="cite_ref-UKChartHistory_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UKChartHistory-74">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> <i>B'Day</i> also produced three other singles; "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Ring_the_Alarm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ring the Alarm (page does not exist)">Ring the Alarm</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Get_Me_Bodied&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Get Me Bodied (page does not exist)">Get Me Bodied</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Green_Light_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Green Light (Beyoncé song) (page does not exist)">Green Light</a>" (released in the United Kingdom only).<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>Her first acting role of 2006 was in the comedy film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Pink_Panther_(2006_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Pink Panther (2006 film) (page does not exist)">The Pink Panther</a></i> starring opposite <a href="/wiki/Steve_Martin" title="Steve Martin">Steve Martin</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> grossing $158.8&#160;million at the box office worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>  Her second film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dreamgirls_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dreamgirls (film) (page does not exist)">Dreamgirls</a>,</i> the film version of the 1981 Broadway musical<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> loosely based on <a href="/wiki/The_Supremes" title="The Supremes">The Supremes</a>, received acclaim from critics and grossed $154&#160;million internationally.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> In it, she starred opposite <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Hudson" title="Jennifer Hudson">Jennifer Hudson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jamie_Foxx" title="Jamie Foxx">Jamie Foxx</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eddie_Murphy" title="Eddie Murphy">Eddie Murphy</a> playing a pop singer based on <a href="/wiki/Diana_Ross" title="Diana Ross">Diana Ross</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> To promote the film, Beyoncé released "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Listen_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Listen (Beyoncé song) (page does not exist)">Listen</a>" as the lead single from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dreamgirls:_Music_from_the_Motion_Picture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dreamgirls: Music from the Motion Picture (page does not exist)">soundtrack album</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> In April 2007, Beyoncé embarked on <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beyonc%C3%A9_Experience&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beyoncé Experience (page does not exist)">The Beyoncé Experience</a>, her first worldwide concert tour, visiting 97 venues<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> and grossed over $24&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[note 1]</a></sup> Beyoncé conducted pre-concert food donation drives during six major stops in conjunction with her pastor at St. John's and <a href="/w/index.php?title=America%27s_Second_Harvest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="America's Second Harvest (page does not exist)">America's Second Harvest</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[89]</a></sup> At the same time, <i>B'Day</i> was re-released with five additional songs, including her duet with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shakira&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shakira (page does not exist)">Shakira</a> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Beautiful_Liar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beautiful Liar (page does not exist)">Beautiful Liar</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[90]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2008.E2.80.9310:_Marriage.2C_I_Am..._Sasha_Fierce.2C_and_Cadillac_Records">2008–10: Marriage, <i>I Am... Sasha Fierce</i>, and <i>Cadillac Records</i></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_smilesea_-_Beyonc%C3%A9_Newcastle_2009_(20).jpg" title="File:Flickr - smilesea - Beyoncé Newcastle 2009 (20).jpg">File:Flickr - smilesea - Beyoncé Newcastle 2009 (20).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Beyoncé performing during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am..._World_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am... World Tour (page does not exist)">I Am... World Tour</a></div></div></div>
<p>On April 4, 2008, Beyoncé married Jay-Z.<sup id="cite_ref-marriage_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-marriage-92">[91]</a></sup> She publicly revealed their marriage in a video montage at the listening party for her third studio album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am..._Sasha_Fierce&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am... Sasha Fierce (page does not exist)">I Am... Sasha Fierce</a></i>, in Manhattan's Sony Club on October 22, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[92]</a></sup> <i>I Am... Sasha Fierce</i> was released on November 18, 2008 in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[93]</a></sup> The album introduces Beyoncé's <a href="/wiki/Alter_ego" title="Alter ego">alter ego</a> Sasha Fierce, conceived during the making of her 2003 single "Crazy in Love" and sold 482,000&#160;copies in its first week, debuted atop the <i>Billboard</i> 200, and gave Beyoncé her third consecutive number-one album in the US.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[94]</a></sup> The album included the number one song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Single_Ladies_(Put_a_Ring_on_It)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It) (page does not exist)">Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)</a>"<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[95]</a></sup> and top-five song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Halo_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Halo (Beyoncé song) (page does not exist)">Halo</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-beyoncehot100_59-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beyoncehot100-59">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[96]</a></sup> Along with being the song that has spent the longest time on the Hot 100 charts in her career,<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[97]</a></sup> its US success helped Beyoncé achieve more top ten singles on the list than any other woman during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aughts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aughts (page does not exist)">2000s</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[98]</a></sup> It also included the successful "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweet_Dreams_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweet Dreams (Beyoncé song) (page does not exist)">Sweet Dreams</a>"<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[99]</a></sup> and singles "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Diva_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diva (Beyoncé song) (page does not exist)">Diva</a>", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Ego_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ego (Beyoncé song) (page does not exist)">Ego</a>", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Broken-Hearted_Girl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Broken-Hearted Girl (page does not exist)">Broken-Hearted Girl</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Video_Phone_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Video Phone (song) (page does not exist)">Video Phone</a>". The music video for "Single Ladies" has been parodied and imitated around the world, spawning the "first major dance craze" of the Internet age according to the <i><a href="/wiki/Toronto_Star" title="Toronto Star">Toronto Star</a></i>.
<sup id="cite_ref-First_dance_craze_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-First_dance_craze-101">[100]</a></sup> The video won several awards, including Best Video at the 2009 <a href="/w/index.php?title=MTV_Europe_Music_Awards_2009&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MTV Europe Music Awards 2009 (page does not exist)">MTV Europe Music Awards</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[101]</a></sup> the 2009 Scottish <a href="/w/index.php?title=MOBO_Awards_2009&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MOBO Awards 2009 (page does not exist)">MOBO Awards</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[102]</a></sup> and the 2009 <a href="/wiki/BET_Awards" title="BET Awards">BET Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[103]</a></sup> At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_MTV_Video_Music_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 MTV Video Music Awards (page does not exist)">2009 MTV Video Music Awards</a>, the video was nominated for nine awards, ultimately winning three including Video of the Year.<sup id="cite_ref-VMA_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VMA-105">[104]</a></sup> Its failure to win the Best Female Video category, which went to American <a href="/wiki/Country_pop" title="Country pop">country pop</a> singer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taylor_Swift&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taylor Swift (page does not exist)">Taylor Swift</a>'s "<a href="/w/index.php?title=You_Belong_with_Me&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="You Belong with Me (page does not exist)">You Belong with Me</a>", <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kanye_West_MTV_Video_Music_Awards_controversy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kanye West MTV Video Music Awards controversy (page does not exist)">led to Kanye West interrupting the ceremony</a> and Beyoncé improvising a re-presentation of Swift's award during her own acceptance speech.<sup id="cite_ref-VMA_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VMA-105">[104]</a></sup> In March 2009, Beyoncé embarked on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am..._World_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am... World Tour (page does not exist)">I Am... World Tour</a>, her second headlining worldwide concert tour, consisting of 108 shows, grossing $119.5&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé continued to take movie roles, starring as <a href="/wiki/Blues" title="Blues">blues</a> singer <a href="/wiki/Etta_James" title="Etta James">Etta James</a> in the 2008 musical biopic, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cadillac_Records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cadillac Records (page does not exist)">Cadillac Records</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-masterson_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-masterson-107">[106]</a></sup> Her performance in the film received praise from critics,<sup id="cite_ref-masterson_107-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-masterson-107">[106]</a></sup> and she garnered several nominations for her portrayal of James, including a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Satellite_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Satellite Award (page does not exist)">Satellite Award</a> nomination for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Satellite_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress_%E2%80%93_Motion_Picture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Satellite Award for Best Supporting Actress – Motion Picture (page does not exist)">Best Supporting Actress</a>, and a <a href="/w/index.php?title=NAACP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NAACP (page does not exist)">NAACP</a> Image Award nomination for <a href="/wiki/NAACP_Image_Award_for_Outstanding_Supporting_Actress_in_a_Motion_Picture" title="NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Motion Picture">Outstanding Supporting Actress</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[107]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[108]</a></sup> Beyoncé donated her entire salary from the film to Phoenix House, an organization of rehabilitation centers for heroin addicts around the country.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[109]</a></sup> On January 20, 2009, Beyoncé performed James' "<a href="/w/index.php?title=At_Last&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="At Last (page does not exist)">At Last</a>" at the First couple's first inaugural dance.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[110]</a></sup> Beyoncé starred opposite <a href="/wiki/Ali_Larter" title="Ali Larter">Ali Larter</a> and <a href="/wiki/Idris_Elba" title="Idris Elba">Idris Elba</a> in the thriller, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Obsessed_(2009_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Obsessed (2009 film) (page does not exist)">Obsessed</a></i>. She played Sharon Charles, a mother and wife who learns of a woman's obsessive behavior over her husband. Although the film received negative reviews from critics,<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[111]</a></sup> the movie did well at the US box office, grossing $68&#160;million&#8212;$60&#160;million more than <i>Cadillac Records</i><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[112]</a></sup>—on a budget of $20&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[113]</a></sup> The fight scene finale between Sharon and the character played by Ali Larter also won the 2010 <a href="/w/index.php?title=MTV_Movie_Award_for_Best_Fight&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MTV Movie Award for Best Fight (page does not exist)">MTV Movie Award for Best Fight</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[114]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=52nd_Annual_Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="52nd Annual Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">52nd Annual Grammy Awards</a>, Beyoncé received ten nominations, including <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Album_of_the_Year" title="Grammy Award for Album of the Year">Album of the Year</a> for <i>I Am... Sasha Fierce</i>, <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Record_of_the_Year" title="Grammy Award for Record of the Year">Record of the Year</a> for "Halo", and <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Song_of_the_Year" title="Grammy Award for Song of the Year">Song of the Year</a> for "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)", among others.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[115]</a></sup> She tied with <a href="/wiki/Lauryn_Hill" title="Lauryn Hill">Lauryn Hill</a> for most Grammy nominations in a single year by a female artist.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[116]</a></sup>  In 2010, Beyoncé was featured on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lady_Gaga&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lady Gaga (page does not exist)">Lady Gaga</a>'s single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Telephone_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Telephone (song) (page does not exist)">Telephone</a>" and its video.<sup id="cite_ref-UKChartHistory_74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UKChartHistory-74">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[117]</a></sup> The song topped the US <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mainstream_Top_40_(Pop_Songs)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mainstream Top 40 (Pop Songs) (page does not exist)">Pop Songs</a> chart, becoming the sixth number-one for both Beyoncé and Gaga, tying them with <a href="/wiki/Mariah_Carey" title="Mariah Carey">Mariah Carey</a> for most number-ones since the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nielsen_Broadcast_Data_Systems&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nielsen Broadcast Data Systems (page does not exist)">Nielsen</a> Top 40 airplay chart launched in 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[118]</a></sup> "Telephone" received a Grammy Award nomination for <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Pop_Collaboration_with_Vocals" title="Grammy Award for Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals">Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé announced that she would be taking a break from her music career at the end of January 2010, heeding her mother's advice, "to live life, to be inspired by things again".<sup id="cite_ref-hiatus_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hiatus-121">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[121]</a></sup> During the break she and her father parted ways as business partners.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[123]</a></sup> Beyoncé's hiatus lasted nine months and saw her visit European cities, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Wall_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Wall of China (page does not exist)">Great Wall of China</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_pyramids" title="Egyptian pyramids">Egyptian pyramids</a>, Australia, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Festivals_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Festivals in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">English music festivals</a> and various museums and ballet performances.<sup id="cite_ref-hiatus_121-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hiatus-121">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2011.E2.80.9312:_4_and_motherhood">2011–12: <i>4</i> and motherhood</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beyonce_(New_York).jpg" title="File:Beyonce (New York).jpg">File:Beyonce (New York).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Beyoncé performing during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=4_Intimate_Nights_with_Beyonc%C3%A9&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="4 Intimate Nights with Beyoncé (page does not exist)">4 Intimate Nights with Beyoncé</a> residency show in August 2011</div></div></div>
<p>In 2011, documents obtained by <a href="/w/index.php?title=WikiLeaks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="WikiLeaks (page does not exist)">WikiLeaks</a> revealed that Beyoncé was one of many entertainers who had received extravagant sums to perform for the family of Libyan ruler <a href="/wiki/Muammar_Gaddafi" title="Muammar Gaddafi">Muammar Gaddafi</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> reported that the music industry was urging them to return the money they earned for the concerts;<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[125]</a></sup> a spokesperson for Beyoncé later confirmed to <i><a href="/wiki/The_Huffington_Post" title="The Huffington Post">The Huffington Post</a></i> that she donated the money to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Clinton_Bush_Haiti_Fund&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Clinton Bush Haiti Fund (page does not exist)">Clinton Bush Haiti Fund</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[126]</a></sup> Later that year she became the first solo female artist to headline the main Pyramid stage at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Glastonbury_Festival_2011&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Glastonbury Festival 2011 (page does not exist)">2011 Glastonbury Festival</a> in over twenty years<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[128]</a></sup> and was named the "Highest Paid Performer Per Minute in the World", having earlier earned £1.25&#160;million for a five-song performance at a private 2010 New Year's Eve party on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Barth%C3%A9lemy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saint Barthélemy (page does not exist)">St. Barts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[130]</a></sup> In April 2011, Beyoncé joined forces with US First Lady <a href="/wiki/Michelle_Obama" title="Michelle Obama">Michelle Obama</a> and the National Association of Broadcasters Education Foundation, to help boost the latter's campaign against <a href="/w/index.php?title=Child_obesity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Child obesity (page does not exist)">child obesity</a><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[131]</a></sup> by reworking her single "Get Me Bodied".<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[132]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Death_of_Osama_bin_Laden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Death of Osama bin Laden (page does not exist)">death of Osama bin Laden</a>, Beyoncé released her cover of the <a href="/wiki/Lee_Greenwood" title="Lee Greenwood">Lee Greenwood</a> song "<a href="/wiki/God_Bless_the_USA" title="God Bless the USA">God Bless the USA</a>", as a charity single to help raise funds for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_Police_and_Fire_Widows%27_and_Children%27s_Benefit_Fund&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York Police and Fire Widows' and Children's Benefit Fund (page does not exist)">New York Police and Fire Widows' and Children's Benefit Fund</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-God_Bless_the_USA_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-God_Bless_the_USA-134">[133]</a></sup>
</p><p>Her fourth album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=4_(Beyonc%C3%A9_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="4 (Beyoncé album) (page does not exist)">4</a></i> was released on June 28, 2011 in the US.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[134]</a></sup> <i>4</i> sold 310,000 copies in its first week and debuted atop the <i>Billboard</i> 200 chart, giving Beyoncé her fourth consecutive number-one album in the US. The album was preceded by two of its singles "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Run_the_World_(Girls)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Run the World (Girls) (page does not exist)">Run the World (Girls)</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Best_Thing_I_Never_Had&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Best Thing I Never Had (page does not exist)">Best Thing I Never Had</a>", which both attained moderate success.<sup id="cite_ref-beyoncehot100_59-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beyoncehot100-59">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UKChartHistory_74-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UKChartHistory-74">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[135]</a></sup> The fourth single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Love_on_Top&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Love on Top (page does not exist)">Love on Top</a>" was a commercial success in the US.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[136]</a></sup> <i>4</i> also produced two other singles, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Countdown_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Countdown (Beyoncé song) (page does not exist)">Countdown</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=End_of_Time_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="End of Time (song) (page does not exist)">End of Time</a>", which received less success, but critical acclaim. <i><a href="/wiki/Essence_(magazine)" title="Essence (magazine)">Essence</a></i> published her writing about her 2010 break as its July 2011 cover story "Eat, Play, Love", which later won her a writing award from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Association_of_Black_Journalists&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Association of Black Journalists (page does not exist)">New York Association of Black Journalists</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[137]</a></sup> Beyoncé took the stage at New York's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roseland_Ballroom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roseland Ballroom (page does not exist)">Roseland Ballroom</a> for four nights of special performances.<sup id="cite_ref-beyonceonline1_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beyonceonline1-139">[138]</a></sup> The musical set on each of the <i>4 Intimate Nights with Beyoncé</i> concerts in mid-August was the entire <i>4</i> album, to a standing room only.<sup id="cite_ref-beyonceonline1_139-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beyonceonline1-139">[138]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beyonc%C3%A9_2012.jpg" title="File:Beyoncé 2012.jpg">File:Beyoncé 2012.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Beyoncé with her daughter Blue Ivy in April 2012</div></div></div>
<p>At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_MTV_Video_Music_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 MTV Video Music Awards (page does not exist)">2011 MTV Video Music Awards</a>, Beyoncé announced that she and Jay-Z were expecting their first child, throwing her microphone on the floor and undoing her blazer at the end of her performance of "Love On Top".<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[139]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[140]</a></sup> Her appearance helped that year's MTV Video Music Awards become the most-watched broadcast in MTV history, pulling in 12.4&#160;million viewers.<sup id="cite_ref-Mitchell_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mitchell-142">[141]</a></sup> Beyoncé received two nominations at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=54th_Annual_Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="54th Annual Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">54th Annual Grammy Awards</a>: <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Rap/Sung_Collaboration" title="Grammy Award for Best Rap/Sung Collaboration">Best Rap/Sung Collaboration</a> for "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Party_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Party (song) (page does not exist)">Party</a>" and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_for_Best_Long_Form_Music_Video&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Award for Best Long Form Music Video (page does not exist)">Best Long Form Music Video</a> for <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am..._World_Tour_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am... World Tour (album) (page does not exist)">I Am... World Tour</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[142]</a></sup> On January 7, 2012, Beyoncé gave birth to a daughter, Blue Ivy Carter, at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York under heavy security.<sup id="cite_ref-nydailynews.com_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nydailynews.com-144">[143]</a></sup>
</p><p>Five months later, she <a href="/w/index.php?title=Revel_Presents:_Beyonc%C3%A9_Live&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Revel Presents: Beyoncé Live (page does not exist)">performed for four nights</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Revel_Atlantic_City&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Revel Atlantic City (page does not exist)">Revel Atlantic City</a>'s Ovation Hall to celebrate the resort's opening, her first performances since giving birth to Blue Ivy.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[145]</a></sup> In December, Beyoncé along with a variety of other celebrities teamed up and produced a video campaign for "Demand A Plan", a bipartisan effort by a group of 950 US mayors and others<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[146]</a></sup> designed to influence the federal government into rethinking its gun control laws, following the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sandy_Hook_Elementary_School_shooting&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting (page does not exist)">Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2013.E2.80.93present:_Beyonc.C3.A9">2013–present: <i>Beyoncé</i></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beyonce_Grown_Woman_2013_Live_(12).jpg" title="File:Beyonce Grown Woman 2013 Live (12).jpg">File:Beyonce Grown Woman 2013 Live (12).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Beyoncé performing "Grown Woman" during The Mrs. Carter Show World Tour</div></div></div>
<p>In January 2013, Destiny's Child released <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Love_Songs_(Destiny%27s_Child_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Love Songs (Destiny's Child album) (page does not exist)">Love Songs</a></i>, a compilation album of romance-themed songs from their previous albums and newly recorded "Nuclear".<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[148]</a></sup> Beyoncé performed the American national anthem singing along with a pre-recorded track at President Obama's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Second_inauguration_of_Barack_Obama&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Second inauguration of Barack Obama (page does not exist)">second inauguration</a> in Washington, D.C.<sup id="cite_ref-secondinauguration_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-secondinauguration-150">[149]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[150]</a></sup> The following month, Beyoncé performed at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XLVII_halftime_show&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Super Bowl XLVII halftime show (page does not exist)">Super Bowl XLVII halftime show</a>, held at the <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Superdome" title="Mercedes-Benz Superdome">Mercedes-Benz Superdome</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans" title="New Orleans">New Orleans</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[151]</a></sup> winning an <a href="/wiki/Emmy_Award" title="Emmy Award">Emmy Award</a> for Best Outstanding Light Design.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[152]</a></sup> The performance stands as the second most tweeted about moment in history at 268,000 tweets per minute.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[153]</a></sup> At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=55th_Annual_Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="55th Annual Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">55th Annual Grammy Awards</a>, Beyoncé won for <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Traditional_R%26B_Performance" title="Grammy Award for Best Traditional R&amp;B Performance">Best Traditional R&amp;B Performance</a> for "Love on Top".<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[154]</a></sup> Her feature-length documentary film, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Life_Is_But_a_Dream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Life Is But a Dream (page does not exist)">Life Is But a Dream</a></i> first aired on <a href="/w/index.php?title=HBO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="HBO (page does not exist)">HBO</a> on February 16, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[155]</a></sup> The film, which she directed and produced herself, featured footage from her childhood, her as mother and businesswoman, recording, rehearsing for live performances, and her return to the spotlight following Blue Ivy's birth.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[156]</a></sup> Its DVD release in November 2013 was accompanied by footage from the Revel Presents: Beyoncé Live concerts and a new song, "God Made You Beautiful".<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[157]</a></sup> In February 2013, Beyoncé signed a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Music_publisher_(popular_music)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Music publisher (popular music) (page does not exist)">global publishing agreement</a> with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Warner/Chappell_Music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Warner/Chappell Music (page does not exist)">Warner/Chappell Music</a>, which would cover her future songwriting and then-upcoming studio album.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>In April, Beyoncé and Jay-Z visited <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cuba&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cuba (page does not exist)">Cuba</a> for their fifth wedding anniversary, their visit came under scrutiny from three <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Congress_of_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Congress of the United States (page does not exist)">members of Congress</a> for potentially breaching the <a href="/w/index.php?title=US_embargo_against_Cuba&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="US embargo against Cuba (page does not exist)">US embargo against Cuba</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cuba_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cuba-160">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[160]</a></sup> Another Republican Congressman expressed, "So, Beyoncé and Jay-Z are in Cuba? Fine by me. Every American should have the right to travel there";<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[161]</a></sup> the trip was later confirmed to be licensed as a "cultural exchange".<sup id="cite_ref-cuba_160-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cuba-160">[159]</a></sup>
Beyoncé's <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Mrs._Carter_Show_World_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Mrs. Carter Show World Tour (page does not exist)">The Mrs. Carter Show World Tour</a> began on April 15 in <a href="/wiki/Belgrade" title="Belgrade">Belgrade</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a> and features 123 dates worldwide that will run until March 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[162]</a></sup> In May, Beyoncé's cover of <a href="/wiki/Amy_Winehouse" title="Amy Winehouse">Amy Winehouse</a>'s "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Back_to_Black_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Back to Black (song) (page does not exist)">Back to Black</a>" with <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_3000" title="André 3000">André 3000</a> on the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Great_Gatsby_(2013_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Great Gatsby (2013 film) (page does not exist)">The Great Gatsby</a></i> <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Great_Gatsby_(soundtrack)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Great Gatsby (soundtrack) (page does not exist)">soundtrack</a> was released.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[163]</a></sup> She was also honorary chair of the 2013 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Met_Gala&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Met Gala (page does not exist)">Met Gala</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[164]</a></sup> Beyoncé voiced Queen Tara in the <a href="/wiki/3D_film" title="3D film">3D</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=CGI_animation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CGI animation (page does not exist)">CGI animated</a> film, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Epic_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Epic (film) (page does not exist)">Epic</a></i>, released by <a href="/wiki/20th_Century_Fox" title="20th Century Fox">20th Century Fox</a> on May 24,<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[165]</a></sup> and recorded an original song for the film, "Rise Up", co-written with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sia_(singer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sia (singer) (page does not exist)">Sia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[166]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé appeared on "You Changed" with Michelle Williams for Kelly Rowland's album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Talk_a_Good_Game&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Talk a Good Game (page does not exist)">Talk a Good Game</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[167]</a></sup> and "Turnt" alongside <a href="/w/index.php?title=2_Chainz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2 Chainz (page does not exist)">2 Chainz</a> for The-Dream's <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=IV_Play&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IV Play (page does not exist)">IV Play</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[168]</a></sup> She also appeared on husband Jay-Z's twelfth studio album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Magna_Carta..._Holy_Grail&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Magna Carta... Holy Grail (page does not exist)">Magna Carta... Holy Grail</a></i>, on a track titled "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Part_II_(On_the_Run)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Part II (On the Run) (page does not exist)">Part II (On the Run)</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[169]</a></sup> and provided additional vocals on the songs  "Tom Ford" and "BBC", where she was credited under the moniker "Third Ward Trill".<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[170]</a></sup> On December 13, 2013, Beyoncé unexpectedly released her fifth <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beyonc%C3%A9_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beyoncé (album) (page does not exist)">self-titled album</a> on the <a href="/wiki/ITunes_Store" title="ITunes Store">iTunes Store</a> without any prior promotion. It was described as a "visual album" due to every track having a music video. The album debuted atop the <i>Billboard</i> 200 chart, giving Beyoncé her fifth consecutive number-one album in the US.<sup id="cite_ref-applePR_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-applePR-172">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5th_Album_Billboard_Debut_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5th_Album_Billboard_Debut-173">[172]</a></sup> This made her the first woman in the chart's history to have her first five studio albums debut at number one.<sup id="cite_ref-5th_Album_Billboard_Debut_173-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5th_Album_Billboard_Debut-173">[172]</a></sup> <i>Beyoncé</i> received critical acclaim<sup id="cite_ref-sisario_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sisario-174">[173]</a></sup> and commercial success, selling 828,773 digital copies in three days;<sup id="cite_ref-applePR_172-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-applePR-172">[171]</a></sup> <i>The New York Times</i> noted the album's unconventional, unexpected release as significant.<sup id="cite_ref-sisario_174-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sisario-174">[173]</a></sup> Musically, an <a href="/wiki/Electro_(music)" title="Electro (music)">electro</a>-<a href="/w/index.php?title=Contemporary_R%26B&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Contemporary R&amp;B (page does not exist)">R&amp;B</a> album, it concerns darker themes unexplored in her work previously such as "<a href="/wiki/Bulimia" title="Bulimia" class="mw-redirect">bulimia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Postpartum_depression" title="Postpartum depression">postnatal depression</a> [and] the fears and insecurities of marriage and motherhood."<sup id="cite_ref-NME_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NME-175">[174]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span></h2>
