<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Family">Family</span></h3>
<p>{{#invoke:anchor|main}}
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beyonc%C3%A9_e_Jay-Z.jpg" title="File:Beyoncé e Jay-Z.jpg">File:Beyoncé e Jay-Z.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Beyoncé performing on the I Am... Tour with Jay-Z, whom she married in 2008 after several years of friendship and dating</div></div></div>
<p>Beyoncé is the eldest child of Mathew and Tina Knowles, who also have another daughter, singer and actress <a href="/wiki/Solange_Knowles" title="Solange Knowles">Solange</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sheridan2011_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sheridan2011-20">[20]</a></sup> Solange has one son Daniel "Julez" J. Smith.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[175]</a></sup> Beyoncé's father had an 18-month affair with actress Alexsandra Wright, who gave birth to their son, Nixon, in February 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-sheridan2011_20-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sheridan2011-20">[20]</a></sup> Her parents' divorce was granted in November 2011 after 31 years of marriage, with Beyoncé severing professional ties with her father shortly after, although she maintains they are not estranged.<sup id="cite_ref-sheridan2011_20-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sheridan2011-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé is believed<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:By_whom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:By whom (page does not exist)">Template:By whom</a> to have first started a relationship with Jay-Z after a collaboration on "<a href="/w/index.php?title=%2703_Bonnie_%26_Clyde&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="'03 Bonnie &amp; Clyde (page does not exist)">'03 Bonnie &amp; Clyde</a>", which appeared on his seventh album <i><a href="/wiki/The_Blueprint_2:_The_Gift_%26_The_Curse" title="The Blueprint 2: The Gift &amp; The Curse">The Blueprint 2: The Gift &amp; The Curse</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[176]</a></sup> Beyoncé appeared as Jay-Z's girlfriend in the music video for the song, which would further fuel speculation of their relationship.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[177]</a></sup> On April 4, 2008, Beyoncé and Jay-Z were married without publicity.<sup id="cite_ref-marriage_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-marriage-92">[91]</a></sup> The couple are known for being private about their relationship, although they have appeared to become more relaxed in recent years.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[178]</a></sup> Beyoncé suffered a miscarriage sometime around 2010 or 2011, describing it as "the saddest thing" she had ever been through.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[179]</a></sup> Beyoncé returned to the studio and wrote music in order to cope with the loss.<sup id="cite_ref-metro2013_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-metro2013-181">[180]</a></sup> In April 2011, Beyoncé and Jay-Z traveled to Paris in order to shoot the album cover for her <i>4</i>; she would fall unexpectedly pregnant here.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[181]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August, the couple attended the 2011 MTV Video Music Awards, in which Beyoncé performed "Love on Top" and started the performance saying "Tonight I want you to stand up on your feet, I want you to feel the love that's growing inside of me".<sup id="cite_ref-mtv2011_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mtv2011-183">[182]</a></sup>  At the end of the performance, Beyoncé dropped her microphone, unbuttoned her blazer and rubbed her stomach, confirming her pregnancy that she had alluded to earlier in the evening.<sup id="cite_ref-mtv2011_183-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mtv2011-183">[182]</a></sup> Her pregnancy announcement earned a <a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Record" title="Guinness World Record" class="mw-redirect">Guinness World Record</a> for "most tweets per second recorded for a single event" on Twitter,<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[183]</a></sup> receiving 8,868 tweets per second<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[184]</a></sup> and "Beyonce pregnant" was the most <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Googled</a> term the week of August 29, 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[185]</a></sup>
</p><p>On January 7, 2012, Beyoncé gave birth to a daughter, Blue Ivy Carter, at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lenox_Hill_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lenox Hill Hospital (page does not exist)">Lenox Hill Hospital</a> in New York under heavy security.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[186]</a></sup> Two days later, Jay-Z released "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Glory_(Jay-Z_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Glory (Jay-Z song) (page does not exist)">Glory</a>", a song dedicated to their child, on his website Lifeandtimes.com. The song detailed the couple's pregnancy struggles, including a miscarriage Beyoncé suffered before becoming pregnant.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[187]</a></sup> Blue Ivy's cries are included at the end of the song, and she was officially credited as B.I.C. on it. At two days old, she became the youngest person ever to appear on a <i>Billboard</i> chart when "Glory" debuted on the Hot R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Songs chart.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[188]</a></sup> The couple unsuccessfully attempted to trademark the name Blue Ivy to start a line of merchandise.<sup id="cite_ref-WP_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WP-190">[189]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[190]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h3>
<p>Beyoncé and husband Jay-Z are friends with President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama. She performed "<a href="/wiki/America_the_Beautiful" title="America the Beautiful">America the Beautiful</a>" at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=First_inauguration_of_Barack_Obama&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="First inauguration of Barack Obama (page does not exist)">2009 presidential inauguration</a>, as well as "At Last" during the first inaugural dance at the Neighborhood Ball two days later.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[191]</a></sup> Beyoncé and Jay-Z held a fundraiser at the latter's 40/40 Club in Manhattan for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Barack_Obama_2012_presidential_campaign&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barack Obama 2012 presidential campaign (page does not exist)">Obama's 2012 presidential campaign</a><sup id="cite_ref-reelection2012_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reelection2012-193">[192]</a></sup> which raised $4&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[193]</a></sup> Beyoncé uploaded pictures of her paper ballot on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tumblr&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tumblr (page does not exist)">Tumblr</a>, confirming she had voted in support for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party (United States) (page does not exist)">Democratic Party</a> and to encourage others to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[194]</a></sup> She also performed the <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_national_anthem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American national anthem (page does not exist)">American national anthem</a> at his second inauguration, singing along with a pre-recorded track.<sup id="cite_ref-secondinauguration_150-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-secondinauguration-150">[149]</a></sup> She publicly endorsed <a href="/wiki/Same_sex_marriage" title="Same sex marriage" class="mw-redirect">same sex marriage</a> on March 26, 2013, after the Supreme Court debate on California's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Proposition_8&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Proposition 8 (page does not exist)">Proposition 8</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[195]</a></sup> In an interview published in <i>Vogue</i> in April 2013, Beyoncé was asked if she considers herself a feminist, to which she gave the ambivalent response, "That word can be very extreme ... But I guess I am a modern-day feminist. I do believe in equality. Why do you have to choose what type of woman you are? Why do you have to label yourself anything? I’m just a woman and I love being a woman. ... I do believe in equality and that we have a way to go and it's something that's pushed aside and something that we have been conditioned to accept. ... But I'm happily married. I love my husband."<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[196]</a></sup> In July 2013, Beyoncé and <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a> attended a rally in response to the acquittal of <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_Zimmerman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George Zimmerman (page does not exist)">George Zimmerman</a> of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shooting_of_Trayvon_Martin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shooting of Trayvon Martin (page does not exist)">shooting of Trayvon Martin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[197]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Wealth">Wealth</span></h3>
<p><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Forbes_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forbes (magazine) (page does not exist)">Forbes</a></i> magazine began reporting on Beyoncé's earnings in 2008, calculating that the $80&#160;million earned between June 2007 to June 2008, for her music, tour, films and clothing line made her the world's best-paid music personality at the time, above <a href="/wiki/Madonna_(entertainer)" title="Madonna (entertainer)">Madonna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Celine_Dion" title="Celine Dion">Celine Dion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[198]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Forb_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forb-200">[199]</a></sup> They placed her fourth on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Forbes_Celebrity_100&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forbes Celebrity 100 (page does not exist)">Celebrity 100</a> list in 2009<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[200]</a></sup>
and ninth on the "Most Powerful Women in the World" list in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[201]</a></sup> The following year, <i>Forbes</i> placed her eighth on the "Best-Paid Celebrities Under 30" list, having earned $35&#160;million in the past year for her clothing line and endorsement deals.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[202]</a></sup> In 2012, <i>Forbes</i> placed Beyoncé at number 16 on the Celebrity 100 list, twelve places lower than three years ago yet still having earned $40&#160;million in the past year for her album <i>4</i>, clothing line and endorsement deals.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[204]</a></sup> and placed her and Jay-Z at number one on the "World's Highest-Paid Celebrity Couples", for collectively earning $78&#160;million in the past year.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[205]</a></sup> The couple made it into the previous year's <i><a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">Guinness Book of Records</a></i> as the "highest-earning power couple" for collectively earning $122&#160;million in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[206]</a></sup> For the years 2009 to 2011, Beyoncé earned an average of $70&#160;million per year, and earned $40&#160;million in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[207]</a></sup> In 2013, Beyoncé's endorsements of Pepsi and H&amp;M made her and Jay-Z the world's first billion dollar couple in the music industry.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[208]</a></sup> That year, Beyoncé was published as the fourth most-powerful celebrity in the <i>Forbes</i> rankings.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[209]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Artistry">Artistry</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Voice_and_songwriting">Voice and songwriting</span></h3>
<div class="quotebox" style="float: right; clear: right; margin: 0.5em 0 0.8em 1.4em; width: 27%; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 90%; background-color: #FFFFF0;">
<div style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
<div style="margin:0px 2em;">
<p>With 'Single Ladies,' clearly I'd just gotten married, and people want to get married every day—then there was the whole Justin Timberlake thing [recreating the video] on "<a href="/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" title="Saturday Night Live">Saturday Night Live</a>," and it was also the year YouTube blew up. With 'Irreplaceable,' the aggressive lyrics, the acoustic guitar, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=808_drums&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="808 drums (page does not exist)">808 drum machine</a>—those things don't typically go together, and it sounded fresh. 'Crazy in Love' was another one of those classic moments in pop culture that none of us expected. I asked Jay to get on the song the night before I had to turn my album in - thank God he did. It still never gets old, no matter how many times I sing it.
</p>
</div>
<div style="position: absolute; left: 0px; top: 0px; text-align: left; font-family:&#39;Times New Roman&#39;,serif; font-weight:bold; font-size: large; color: gray;">“</div>
<div style="position: absolute; right: 0px; bottom: 0px; text-align: left; font-family:&#39;Times New Roman&#39;,serif; font-weight:bold; font-size: large; color: gray;">”</div></div>
<div style="text-align: center;">— Beyoncé<sup id="cite_ref-billboard_q.26a_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-billboard_q.26a-211">[210]</a></sup></div>
</div>
<p>Beyoncé's vocal range spans 3.6 octaves.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[211]</a></sup>  She has been identified as the centerpiece of Destiny's Child.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[212]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_Mail" title="Daily Mail">Daily Mail</a></i> calls Beyoncé's voice "versatile", capable of exploring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Power_ballads&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Power ballads (page does not exist)">power ballads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soul_music" title="Soul music">soul</a>, rock <a href="/w/index.php?title=Belt_(music)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Belt (music) (page does not exist)">belting</a>, operatic flourishes, and hip hop.<sup id="cite_ref-Associated_Newspapers_Ltd_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Associated_Newspapers_Ltd-214">[213]</a></sup> Jon Pareles of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> commented that her voice is "velvety yet tart, with an insistent flutter and reserves of soul <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vocal_belting&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vocal belting (page does not exist)">belting</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-Pareles_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pareles-215">[214]</a></sup> Other critics praise her range and power, with Jody Rosen of <i><a href="/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly" title="Entertainment Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a></i> describing her as "a storm system disguised as a singer"<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[215]</a></sup> and Chris Richards of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i> saying she was "capable of punctuating any beat with goose-bump-inducing whispers or full-bore diva-roars."<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[216]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Side_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Side box (page does not exist)">Template:Side box</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Main_other&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Main other (page does not exist)">Template:Main other</a>
</p><p>Beyoncé's music is generally <a href="/w/index.php?title=Contemporary_R%26B&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Contemporary R&amp;B (page does not exist)">R&amp;B</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[217]</a></sup> but she also incorporates <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[218]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Soul_music" title="Soul music">soul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Funk" title="Funk">funk</a> into her songs. <i>4</i> demonstrated Beyoncé's exploration of 90s-style R&amp;B, as well as further use of soul and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hip_hop_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hip hop music (page does not exist)">hip hop</a> than compared to previous releases.<sup id="cite_ref-billboard_q.26a_211-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-billboard_q.26a-211">[210]</a></sup> While she almost exclusively releases English songs, Beyoncé recorded several Spanish songs for <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Irreemplazable&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Irreemplazable (page does not exist)">Irreemplazable</a></i> (re-recordings of songs from <i>B'Day</i> for a Spanish-language audience), and the re-release of <i>B'Day</i>. To record these, Beyoncé was coached phonetically by American record producer Rudy Perez.<sup id="cite_ref-Vineyard1_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vineyard1-220">[219]</a></sup>
</p><p>She has received co-writing credits for most of the songs recorded with Destiny's Child and her solo efforts.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup> Her early songs were personally driven and female-empowerment themed compositions like "Independent Women" and "Survivor", but after the start of her relationship with Jay-Z she transitioned to more man-tending anthems such as "Cater 2 U".<sup id="cite_ref-Vineyard_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vineyard-221">[220]</a></sup> Beyoncé has also received co-producing credits for most of the records in which she has been involved, especially during her solo efforts. However, she does not formulate <a href="/wiki/Beat_(music)" title="Beat (music)">beats</a> herself, but typically comes up with melodies and ideas during production, sharing them with producers.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[221]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2001 she become the first African-American woman and second woman songwriter to win the Pop Songwriter of the Year award at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Society_of_Composers,_Authors,_and_Publishers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (page does not exist)">American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers</a> Pop Music Awards.<sup id="cite_ref-FOX_18-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOX-18">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CBS_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBS-223">[222]</a></sup> Beyoncé was the third woman to have writing credits on three number one songs ("Irreplaceable", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Grillz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grillz (page does not exist)">Grillz</a>" and "Check on It") in the same year, after <a href="/wiki/Carole_King" title="Carole King">Carole King</a> in 1971 and Mariah Carey in 1991. She is tied with American songwriter <a href="/wiki/Diane_Warren" title="Diane Warren">Diane Warren</a> at third with nine songwriting credits on number-one singles.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[223]</a></sup> (The latter wrote her <a href="/w/index.php?title=September_11_attacks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="September 11 attacks (page does not exist)">9/11</a>-motivated song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Was_Here_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Was Here (song) (page does not exist)">I Was Here</a>" for <i>4.</i><sup id="cite_ref-DianeWarren_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DianeWarren-225">[224]</a></sup>) In May 2011, <i>Billboard</i> magazine listed Beyoncé at number 17 on their list of the "Top 20 Hot 100 Songwriters", for having co-written eight singles that hit number one on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 chart. She was one of only three women on that list.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[225]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Influences">Influences</span></h3>
<p>Beyoncé names Michael Jackson as her major musical influence and idol.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[226]</a></sup> She admires Diana Ross as an "all-around entertainer"<sup id="cite_ref-Beyonce.27s_Inspirations_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beyonce.27s_Inspirations-228">[227]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Whitney_Houston" title="Whitney Houston">Whitney Houston</a> whom she said "inspired me to get up there and do what she did."<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[228]</a></sup> Beyoncé credits Mariah Carey's singing and her song "<a href="/wiki/Vision_of_Love" title="Vision of Love">Vision of Love</a>" as influencing her to begin practicing vocal runs as a child, as well as helping her pursue a career as a musician.<sup id="cite_ref-new_yorker_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-new_yorker-230">[229]</a></sup>  Her other musical influences include <a href="/wiki/Cher" title="Cher">Cher</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[230]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Prince_(musician)" title="Prince (musician)">Prince</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[231]</a></sup> Lauryn Hill,<sup id="cite_ref-Beyonce.27s_Inspirations_228-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beyonce.27s_Inspirations-228">[227]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sade_Adu" title="Sade Adu">Sade</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[232]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Aaliyah" title="Aaliyah">Aaliyah</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[233]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Donna_Summer" title="Donna Summer">Donna Summer</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[234]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mary_J._Blige" title="Mary J. Blige">Mary J. Blige</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[235]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Janet_Jackson" title="Janet Jackson">Janet Jackson</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[236]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anita_Baker" title="Anita Baker">Anita Baker</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rachelle_Ferrell" title="Rachelle Ferrell">Rachelle Ferrell</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Beyonce.27s_Inspirations_228-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beyonce.27s_Inspirations-228">[227]</a></sup>
</p><p>The feminism and female empowerment themes on Beyoncé's second solo album <i>B'Day</i> were inspired by her role in <i>Dreamgirls</i><sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[237]</a></sup> and by singer <a href="/wiki/Josephine_Baker" title="Josephine Baker">Josephine Baker</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[238]</a></sup> Beyoncé paid homage to Baker by performing "Déjà Vu" at the 2006 Fashion Rocks concert wearing Baker's trademark mini-hula skirt embellished with fake bananas.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[239]</a></sup> Beyoncé's third solo album <i>I Am... Sasha Fierce</i> was inspired by Jay-Z and especially by Etta James, whose "boldness" inspired Beyoncé to explore other musical genres and styles.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[240]</a></sup> Her fourth solo album <i>4</i> was inspired by Fela Kuti, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Contemporary_R%26B&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Contemporary R&amp;B (page does not exist)">1990s R&amp;B</a>, <a href="/wiki/Earth,_Wind_%26_Fire" title="Earth, Wind &amp; Fire">Earth, Wind &amp; Fire</a>, <a href="/wiki/DeBarge" title="DeBarge">DeBarge</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Richie" title="Lionel Richie">Lionel Richie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Teena_Marie" title="Teena Marie">Teena Marie</a> with additional influences by <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Jackson_5&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Jackson 5 (page does not exist)">The Jackson 5</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Edition" title="New Edition">New Edition</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adele_(singer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adele (singer) (page does not exist)">Adele</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Florence_and_the_Machine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Florence and the Machine (page does not exist)">Florence and the Machine</a>, and Prince.<sup id="cite_ref-billboard_q.26a_211-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-billboard_q.26a-211">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé has stated that she is personally inspired by <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_First_Lady&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States First Lady (page does not exist)">US First Lady</a> Michelle Obama, saying "She proves you can do it all"<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[241]</a></sup> and she has described <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oprah_Winfrey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oprah Winfrey (page does not exist)">Oprah Winfrey</a> as "the definition of inspiration and a strong woman."<sup id="cite_ref-Beyonce.27s_Inspirations_228-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beyonce.27s_Inspirations-228">[227]</a></sup>  She also has discussed how Jay-Z is a continuing inspiration to her, both with what she describes as his lyrical genius and in the obstacles he has overcome in his life.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[242]</a></sup> Beyoncé has expressed admiration for the artist <a href="/wiki/Jean-Michel_Basquiat" title="Jean-Michel Basquiat">Jean-Michel Basquiat</a>, posting in a letter "what I find in the work of Jean-Michel Basquiat, I search for in every day in music...he is lyrical and raw".<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[243]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[244]</a></sup> In February 2013, Beyoncé said that <a href="/wiki/Madonna_(entertainer)" title="Madonna (entertainer)">Madonna</a> inspired her to take control of her own career. She commented: "I think about Madonna and how she took all of the great things she achieved and started the label and developed other artists. But there are not enough of those women.".<sup id="cite_ref-Beyonce_and_Madonna_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beyonce_and_Madonna-246">[245]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Stage_and_alter_ego">Stage and alter ego</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beyonc%C3%A9_Knowles_GMA_Run_the_World.jpg" title="File:Beyoncé Knowles GMA Run the World.jpg">File:Beyoncé Knowles GMA Run the World.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Beyoncé performing "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Run_the_World_(Girls)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Run the World (Girls) (page does not exist)">Run the World (Girls)</a>" on the 2011 <i><a href="/wiki/Good_Morning_America" title="Good Morning America">Good Morning America</a></i> Summer Concert Series</div></div></div>
<p>In 2006, Beyoncé introduced her all-female tour band Suga Mama (also the name of a song in <i>B'Day</i>) which includes bassists, drummers, guitarists, horn players, keyboardists and percussionists.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[246]</a></sup> Her background singers, The Mamas, consist of Montina Cooper-Donnell, Crystal Collins and Tiffany Moniqué Riddick. They made their debut appearance at the 2006 BET Awards and re-appeared in the music videos for "Irreplaceable" and "Green Light".<sup id="cite_ref-Vineyard1_220-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vineyard1-220">[219]</a></sup> The band have supported Beyoncé in most subsequent live performances, including her 2007 concert tour The Beyoncé Experience, 2009–2010 I Am... World Tour and 2013–2014 The Mrs. Carter Show World Tour.
</p><p>Beyoncé has received praise for her stage presence and voice during live performances. Jarett Wieselman of the <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Post" title="New York Post">New York Post</a></i> placed her at number one on her list of the Five Best Singer/Dancers.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[247]</a></sup> According to Barbara Ellen of <i>The Guardian</i> Beyoncé is the most in-charge female artist she's seen onstage,<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[248]</a></sup> while Alice Jones of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Independent" title="The Independent">The Independent</a></i> wrote she "takes her role as entertainer so seriously she's almost too good."<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[249]</a></sup> Tamara Hardingham-Gill of the <i>Daily Mail</i> wrote that "many industry experts have been tipping Beyoncé as the next Michael Jackson".<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[250]</a></sup> The ex-President of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Def_Jam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Def Jam (page does not exist)">Def Jam</a> <a href="/wiki/L.A._Reid" title="L.A. Reid">L.A. Reid</a> has described Beyoncé as the greatest entertainer alive.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[251]</a></sup> Jim Farber of the <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_News_(New_York)" title="Daily News (New York)">Daily News</a></i> and Stephanie Classen of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Star_Phoenix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Star Phoenix (page does not exist)">Star Phoenix</a></i> both praised her strong voice and her stage presence.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[252]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[253]</a></sup>
</p><p>Described as being "sexy, seductive and provocative" when performing on stage, Beyoncé has said that she originally created the alter ego "Sasha Fierce" to keep that stage persona separate from who she really is.<sup id="cite_ref-Depression_36-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Depression-36">[36]</a></sup> She described Sasha as being "too aggressive, too strong, too sassy [and] too sexy", stating, "I'm not like her in real life at all."<sup id="cite_ref-Depression_36-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Depression-36">[36]</a></sup> Sasha was conceived during the making of "Crazy in Love", and Beyoncé introduced her with the release of her 2008 album <i>I Am... Sasha Fierce</i>. In February 2010, she announced in an interview with <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Allure_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Allure (magazine) (page does not exist)">Allure</a></i> magazine that she was comfortable enough with herself to no longer need Sasha Fierce.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[254]</a></sup> However, Beyoncé announced in May 2012 that she would bring her back for her <i>Revel Presents: Beyoncé Live</i> shows later that month.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[255]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_image">Public image</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beyonce_Dreamgirls_cropped.jpg" title="File:Beyonce Dreamgirls cropped.jpg">File:Beyonce Dreamgirls cropped.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Beyoncé at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Movie_premiere&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Movie premiere (page does not exist)">premiere</a> for her 2006 film, <i>Dreamgirls</i></div></div></div>
<p>Beyoncé has been described as a having a wide-ranging sex appeal, with music journalist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tour%C3%A9&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Touré (page does not exist)">Touré</a> writing that since the release of <i>Dangerously in Love</i>, she has "become a crossover sex symbol"<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[256]</a></sup> Off stage Beyoncé says that while she likes to dress sexily her onstage dress "is absolutely for the stage."<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[257]</a></sup> Due to her curves and the term's catchiness, in the 2000s the media often used the term "Bootylicious" (a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Portmanteau&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Portmanteau (page does not exist)">portmanteau</a> of the words <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buttocks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buttocks (page does not exist)">booty</a> and delicious) to describe Beyoncé,<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[258]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[259]</a></sup> the term popularized by Destiny's Child in the single of the same name. In 2006, it was added to the <a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[260]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:External_media&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:External media (page does not exist)">Template:External media</a>
In September 2010, Beyoncé made her runway modelling debut at <a href="/wiki/Tom_Ford" title="Tom Ford">Tom Ford</a>'s Spring/Summer 2011 fashion show.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[261]</a></sup> She was named "<a href="/w/index.php?title=People_Magazine%27s_100_Most_Beautiful_People&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="People Magazine's 100 Most Beautiful People (page does not exist)">World's Most Beautiful Woman</a>" by <i>People</i><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[262]</a></sup> and the "Hottest Female Singer of All Time" by <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Complex_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Complex (magazine) (page does not exist)">Complex</a></i> in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[263]</a></sup> In January 2013, <i><a href="/wiki/GQ" title="GQ">GQ</a></i> placed her on its cover, featuring her atop its "100 Sexiest Women of the 21st Century" list.<sup id="cite_ref-GQstory_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GQstory-265">[264]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[265]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/VH1" title="VH1">VH1</a> listed her at number 1 on its 100 Sexiest Artists list.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[266]</a></sup> Several <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wax_figure&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wax figure (page does not exist)">wax figures</a> of Beyoncé are found at <a href="/wiki/Madame_Tussaud" title="Madame Tussaud" class="mw-redirect">Madame Tussauds</a> Wax Museums in major cities around the world, including New York,<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[267]</a></sup> Washington, D.C.,<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[268]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Amsterdam" title="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[269]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bangkok" title="Bangkok">Bangkok</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[270]</a></sup> Hollywood<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[271]</a></sup> and Sydney.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[272]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Italian fashion designer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roberto_Cavalli&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roberto Cavalli (page does not exist)">Roberto Cavalli</a>, Beyoncé uses different fashion styles to work with her music while performing.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[273]</a></sup> Her mother co-wrote a book, published in 2002, titled <i>Destiny's Style</i><sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[274]</a></sup> an account of how fashion had an impact on the trio's success.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[275]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=B%27Day_Anthology_Video_Album&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="B'Day Anthology Video Album (page does not exist)">B'Day Anthology Video Album</a></i> showed many instances of fashion-oriented footage, depicting classic to contemporary wardrobe styles.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[276]</a></sup> In 2007, Beyoncé was featured on the cover of the <i><a href="/wiki/Sports_Illustrated_Swimsuit_Issue" title="Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue">Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue</a></i>, becoming the second African American woman after <a href="/wiki/Tyra_Banks" title="Tyra Banks">Tyra Banks</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-People2_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-People2-278">[277]</a></sup> and <i>People</i> magazine recognized Beyoncé as the best-dressed celebrity.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[278]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <i>Bey Hive</i> is the name given to Beyoncé's fan base.  Fans were previously titled "The Beyontourage," (a portmanteau of Beyoncé and entourage).  The name Bey Hive derives from the word <a href="/wiki/Beehive" title="Beehive">beehive</a>, purposely misspelled to resemble her first name, and was penned by fans after petitions on the online <a href="/wiki/Social_networking_service" title="Social networking service">social networking service</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Twitter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Twitter (page does not exist)">Twitter</a> and online news reports during competitions.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[279]</a></sup> 
</p><p>In 2006, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_rights&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal rights (page does not exist)">animal rights</a> organization <a href="/wiki/People_for_the_Ethical_Treatment_of_Animals" title="People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals">People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals</a> (PETA), criticized Beyoncé for wearing and using fur in her clothing line <a href="/w/index.php?title=House_of_Der%C3%A9on&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="House of Deréon (page does not exist)">House of Deréon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-PETA_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PETA-281">[280]</a></sup> In 2011, she appeared on the cover of French fashion magazine <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=L%27Officiel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="L'Officiel (page does not exist)">L'Officiel</a></i>, in blackface and tribal makeup that drew criticism from the media. A statement released from a spokesperson for the magazine said that Beyoncé's look was "far from the glamorous Sasha Fierce" and that it was "a return to her African roots".<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[281]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé's lighter skin color and costuming has drawn criticism from some in the African-American community.<sup id="cite_ref-Jones_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jones-283">[282]</a></sup> Emmett Price, a professor of music at Northeastern University, wrote in 2007, that he thinks race plays a role in many of these criticisms, saying white celebrities who dress similarly do not attract as many comments.<sup id="cite_ref-Jones_283-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jones-283">[282]</a></sup> In 2008, L'Oreal was accused of whitening her skin in their <a href="/wiki/Feria" title="Feria">Feria</a> hair color advertisements, responding that "it is categorically untrue",<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[283]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[284]</a></sup> and in 2013, Beyoncé herself criticized H&amp;M for their proposed "retouching" of promotional images of her, and according to <i><a href="/wiki/Vogue_(magazine)" title="Vogue (magazine)">Vogue</a></i> requested that only "natural pictures be used".<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[285]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beyonc%C3%A9_-_Pavilh%C3%A3o_Atl%C3%A2ntico.jpg" title="File:Beyoncé - Pavilhão Atlântico.jpg">File:Beyoncé - Pavilhão Atlântico.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Beyoncé performing during her <a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am..._Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am... Tour (page does not exist)">I Am... Tour</a> in 2009</div></div></div>
<p>In <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Yorker" title="The New Yorker">The New Yorker</a></i> music critic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jody_Rosen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jody Rosen (page does not exist)">Jody Rosen</a> described Beyoncé as "the most important and compelling popular musician of the twenty-first century ... the result, the logical end point, of a century-plus of pop."<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[286]</a></sup> Beyoncé has continuously drawn comparison to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Jackson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Jackson (page does not exist)">Michael Jackson</a> for her powerful stage presence and impact on the music industry, also being referred to as the "heir-apparent to Michael Jackson's legacy".<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[287]</a></sup> In 2013, Beyoncé made the <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> 100 list, <a href="/wiki/Baz_Luhrmann" title="Baz Luhrmann">Baz Luhrmann</a> writing "no one has that voice, no one moves the way she moves, no one can hold an audience the way she does... When Beyoncé does an album, when Beyoncé sings a song, when Beyoncé does anything, it's an event, and it's broadly influential. Right now, she is the heir-­apparent diva of the USA — the reigning national voice."<sup id="cite_ref-time2013_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time2013-289">[288]</a></sup> When <i>The Guardian</i> named her Artist of the Decade, Llewyn-Smith wrote "Why Beyoncé?...Because she made not one but two of the decade's greatest singles, with Crazy in Love and Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It), not to mention her hits with Destiny's Child; and this was the decade when singles&#8212;particularly R&amp;B singles&#8212;regained their status as pop's favourite medium...she and not any superannuated rock star was arguably the greatest live performer of the past 10 years."<sup id="cite_ref-smith_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-smith-290">[289]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé's work has influenced numerous artists including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adele&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adele (page does not exist)">Adele</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[290]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rihanna" title="Rihanna">Rihanna</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[291]</a></sup> Kelly Rowland,<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[292]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[293]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leona_Lewis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leona Lewis (page does not exist)">Leona Lewis</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[294]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Misha_B&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Misha B (page does not exist)">Misha B</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[295]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nicole_Scherzinger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nicole Scherzinger (page does not exist)">Nicole Scherzinger</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[296]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rita_Ora&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rita Ora (page does not exist)">Rita Ora</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[297]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jessie_J&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jessie J (page does not exist)">Jessie J</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[298]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Azealia_Banks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Azealia Banks (page does not exist)">Azealia Banks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[299]</a></sup> American <a href="/wiki/Indie_rock" title="Indie rock">indie rock</a> band <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_Rabbits_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White Rabbits (band) (page does not exist)">White Rabbits</a> also cited her an inspiration for their third album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Milk_Famous&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Milk Famous (page does not exist)">Milk Famous</a></i> (2012),<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[300]</a></sup> friend <a href="/wiki/Gwyneth_Paltrow" title="Gwyneth Paltrow">Gwyneth Paltrow</a><sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[301]</a></sup> studied Beyoncé at her live concerts while learning to become a musical performer for the 2010 film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Country_Strong&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Country Strong (page does not exist)">Country Strong</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[302]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nicki_Minaj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nicki Minaj (page does not exist)">Nicki Minaj</a> has stated that seeing Beyoncé's Pepsi commercial influenced her decision to appear in the company's 2012 global campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[303]</a></sup>
</p><p>Her debut single, "Crazy in Love" was named VH1's "Greatest Song of the 2000s",<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[304]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/NME" title="NME">NME</a></i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:%27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:' (page does not exist)">Template:'s</a> "Best Track of the 00s"<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[305]</a></sup> and "Pop Song of the Century",<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[306]</a></sup> considered by <i>Rolling Stone</i> to be one of <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_500_greatest_songs_of_all_time&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The 500 greatest songs of all time (page does not exist)">the 500 greatest songs of all time</a>, earned two Grammy Awards and is one of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Best-selling_singles_worldwide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Best-selling singles worldwide (page does not exist)">best-selling singles of all time</a> at around 8&#160;million copies. The music video for "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)", which achieved fame for its intricate choreography<sup id="cite_ref-singleladiesdance2_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-singleladiesdance2-308">[307]</a></sup> and its deployment of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jazz_hands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jazz hands (page does not exist)">jazz hands</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[308]</a></sup> was credited by the <i>Toronto Star</i> as having started the "first major dance craze of both the new millennium and the Internet",<sup id="cite_ref-First_dance_craze_101-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-First_dance_craze-101">[100]</a></sup> triggering a number of parodies of the dance choreography<sup id="cite_ref-singleladies1_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-singleladies1-310">[309]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[310]</a></sup> and a legion of amateur imitators on YouTube.<sup id="cite_ref-singleladiesdance2_308-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-singleladiesdance2-308">[307]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-singleladies1_310-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-singleladies1-310">[309]</a></sup> In 2013, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Drake_(entertainer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drake (entertainer) (page does not exist)">Drake</a> released a single titled "Girls Love Beyoncé", which featured an interpolation from Destiny Child's "Say My Name" and discussed his relationship with women.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[311]</a></sup>  In January 2012, research scientist Bryan Lessard named <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Scaptia_beyonceae&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scaptia beyonceae (page does not exist)">Scaptia beyonceae</a></i>, a species of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Horse_fly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Horse fly (page does not exist)">horse fly</a> found in <a href="/w/index.php?title=North_Queensland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="North Queensland (page does not exist)">Northern Queensland</a>, Australia after Beyoncé due to the fly's unique golden hairs on its abdomen.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[312]</a></sup> Later that month, a course around Beyoncé's meaning in culture called "Politicizing Beyoncé" was introduced at <a href="/wiki/Rutgers_University" title="Rutgers University">Rutgers University</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-rutgerscourse_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rutgerscourse-314">[313]</a></sup> The course allows students to explore the "social and cultural significance" of Beyoncé's music and image, including her alter ego Sasha Fierce and whether her "racy performances" are of female sexual empowerment or "merely complying with western gender stereotypes".<sup id="cite_ref-rutgerscourse_314-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rutgerscourse-314">[313]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Honors_and_awards">Honors and awards</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Beyoncé has earned numerous awards and honors. As a solo artist she has sold over 13&#160;million albums in the US, and over 118&#160;million records worldwide (a further 60 million additionally with <a href="/wiki/Destiny%27s_Child" title="Destiny's Child">Destiny's Child</a>), making her one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">best-selling music artists</a> of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-2012CareerSales_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2012CareerSales-8">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Newstateman_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Newstateman-315">[314]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recording_Industry_Association_of_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recording Industry Association of America (page does not exist)">Recording Industry Association of America</a> (RIAA) listed Beyoncé as the top certified artist of the 2000s, with a total of 64 <a href="/wiki/RIAA_certification" title="RIAA certification">certifications</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-RIAADecade1_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RIAADecade1-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RIAADecade2_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RIAADecade2-11">[11]</a></sup> Her songs "Crazy in Love", "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)", "Halo" and "Irreplaceable" are some of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_best-selling_singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of best-selling singles (page does not exist)">best-selling singles of all time worldwide</a>. In 2009, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Observer" title="The Observer">The Observer</a></i> named her the Artist of the Decade<sup id="cite_ref-smith_290-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-smith-290">[289]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Billboard_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Billboard (magazine) (page does not exist)">Billboard</a></i> named her the Top Female Artist and Top Radio Songs Artist of the Decade.<sup id="cite_ref-RadioSongsArtist_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RadioSongsArtist-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ChartBeat_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChartBeat-316">[315]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DecadeChart_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DecadeChart-317">[316]</a></sup> In 2010, <i>Billboard</i> named her in their "Top 50 R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Artists of the Past 25 Years" list at number 15.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[317]</a></sup> In 2012 VH1 ranked her third on their list of the "100 Greatest Women in Music".<sup id="cite_ref-VH1GreatestWomen_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VH1GreatestWomen-319">[318]</a></sup> Beyoncé was the first female artist to be honored with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Music_Awards_of_2007&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Music Awards of 2007 (page does not exist)">International Artist Award</a> at the <a href="/wiki/American_Music_Award" title="American Music Award">American Music Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[319]</a></sup> She has also received the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Music_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Music Awards (page does not exist)">Legend Award for Outstanding Contribution to the Arts</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_World_Music_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 World Music Awards (page does not exist)">2008 World Music Awards</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Music_Award#Billboard_Millennium_Award" title="Billboard Music Award">Billboard Millennium Award</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Billboard_Music_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Billboard Music Awards (page does not exist)">2011 Billboard Music Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[320]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé has won 17 <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">Grammy Awards</a>, both as a solo artist and member of Destiny's Child, making her the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Award records (page does not exist)">third most honored female artist</a> by the Grammys, behind <a href="/wiki/Alison_Krauss" title="Alison Krauss">Alison Krauss</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aretha_Franklin" title="Aretha Franklin">Aretha Franklin</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-HonoredArtist_322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HonoredArtist-322">[321]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-GrammyTotal_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GrammyTotal-323">[322]</a></sup> and the most nominated woman in Grammy Award history. "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)" won Song of the Year in 2010 while "Say My Name"<sup id="cite_ref-Kaufman_28-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaufman-28">[28]</a></sup> and "Crazy in Love" had previously won Best R&amp;B Song. <i>Dangerously in Love</i>, <i>B'Day</i> and <i>I Am... Sasha Fierce</i> have all won Best Contemporary R&amp;B Album. Beyoncé set the record for the most <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Award records (page does not exist)">Grammy awards won by a female artist in one night</a> in 2010 when she won six awards, breaking the tie she previously held with Alicia Keys, <a href="/wiki/Norah_Jones" title="Norah Jones">Norah Jones</a>, Alison Krauss, and Amy Winehouse,<sup id="cite_ref-Grammy_2010_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Grammy_2010-324">[323]</a></sup> with Adele equaling this in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[324]</a></sup>  Following her role in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dreamgirls_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dreamgirls (film) (page does not exist)">Dreamgirls</a></i> she was nominated for <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Original_Song" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Original Song">Best Original Song</a> for "Listen" and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Actress_-_Motion_Picture_Musical_or_Comedy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Actress - Motion Picture Musical or Comedy (page does not exist)">Best Actress</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golden_Globe_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golden Globe Awards (page does not exist)">Golden Globe Awards</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[325]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/NAACP_Image_Award_for_Outstanding_Actress_in_a_Motion_Picture" title="NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Actress in a Motion Picture">Outstanding Actress in a Motion Picture</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=NAACP_Image_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NAACP Image Awards (page does not exist)">NAACP Image Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[326]</a></sup> Beyoncé won two awards at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=12th_Critics%27_Choice_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="12th Critics' Choice Awards (page does not exist)">Broadcast Film Critics Association Awards 2006</a>; Best Song for "Listen" and Best Original Soundtrack for <i>Dreamgirls: Music from the Motion Picture</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[327]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_ventures">Other ventures</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Endorsements">Endorsements</span></h3>
<p>Beyoncé has worked with Pepsi since 2002,<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[328]</a></sup> and in 2004 appeared in a <a href="/wiki/Gladiator" title="Gladiator">Gladiator</a>-themed commercial with Britney Spears, <a href="/wiki/Pink_(singer)" title="Pink (singer)">Pink</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Iglesias" title="Enrique Iglesias">Enrique Iglesias</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[329]</a></sup> In 2012, Beyoncé signed a $50&#160;million deal to endorse Pepsi.<sup id="cite_ref-pepsi2013_331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pepsi2013-331">[330]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Center_for_Science_in_the_Public_Interest" title="Center for Science in the Public Interest">Center for Science in the Public Interest</a> (CSPINET) wrote Beyoncé an open letter asking her to reconsider the deal because of the unhealthiness of the product and to donate the proceeds to a medical organisation.<sup id="cite_ref-rumugam_332-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rumugam-332">[331]</a></sup> Nevertheless, <a href="/w/index.php?title=NetBase&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NetBase (page does not exist)">NetBase</a> found that Beyoncé's campaign was the most talked about endorsement in April 2013, with a 70 per cent positive audience response to the commercial and print ads.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[332]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé has worked with <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Hilfiger" title="Tommy Hilfiger">Tommy Hilfiger</a> for the fragrances True Star<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[333]</a></sup> (singing a <a href="/wiki/Cover_version" title="Cover version">cover version</a> of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Wishing_on_a_Star&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wishing on a Star (page does not exist)">Wishing on a Star</a>")<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[334]</a></sup> and True Star Gold;<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[335]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[336]</a></sup> she also promoted <a href="/wiki/Emporio_Armani" title="Emporio Armani" class="mw-redirect">Emporio Armani</a>'s Diamonds fragrance in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[337]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[338]</a></sup> Beyoncé launched her first official fragrance, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Heat_(fragrance)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heat (fragrance) (page does not exist)">Heat</a> in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[339]</a></sup> The commercial, which featured the 1956 song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fever_(1956_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fever (1956 song) (page does not exist)">Fever</a>", was shown after the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Watershed_(television)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Watershed (television) (page does not exist)">water shed</a> in the United Kingdom as it begins with an image of Beyoncé appearing to lie naked in a room.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[340]</a></sup> In February 2011, Beyoncé launched her second fragrance, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Heat_(fragrance)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heat (fragrance) (page does not exist)">Heat Rush</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[341]</a></sup> Beyoncé's third fragrance, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pulse_(perfume)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pulse (perfume) (page does not exist)">Pulse</a>, was launched in September 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[342]</a></sup> In 2013, The Mrs. Carter Show Limited Edition version of Heat was released.<sup id="cite_ref-heatsales_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-heatsales-344">[343]</a></sup> The six editions of Heat are the world's best-selling celebrity fragrance,<sup id="cite_ref-heatsales_344-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-heatsales-344">[343]</a></sup> with sales of over $400&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[344]</a></sup>
</p><p>The release of a video-game <i>Starpower: Beyoncé</i> was cancelled after Beyoncé pulled out of a $100&#160;million with GateFive who alleged the cancellation meant the sacking of 70 staff and millions of pounds lost in development.<sup id="cite_ref-GateFive_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GateFive-346">[345]</a></sup> It was settled out of court by her lawyers in June 2013 who said that they had cancelled because GateFive had lost its financial backers.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[346]</a></sup> Beyoncé also has had deals with <a href="/wiki/American_Express" title="American Express">American Express</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Forb_200-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forb-200">[199]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nintendo_DS" title="Nintendo DS">Nintendo DS</a><sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[347]</a></sup> and L'Oreal since the age of 18.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[348]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion_lines">Fashion lines</span></h3>
<p>Beyoncé and her mother introduced House of Deréon, a contemporary women's fashion line, in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-BusWire_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BusWire-350">[349]</a></sup> The concept is inspired by three generations of women in their family, the name paying tribute to Beyoncé's grandmother, Agnèz Deréon, a respected seamstress.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[350]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[351]</a></sup> According to Tina, the overall style of the line best reflects her and Beyoncé's taste and style.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[352]</a></sup> Beyoncé and her mother founded their family's company Beyond Productions, which provides the licensing and brand management for House of Deréon, and its junior collection, Deréon.<sup id="cite_ref-BusWire_350-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BusWire-350">[349]</a></sup> House of Deréon pieces were exhibited in Destiny's Child's shows and tours, during their <i>Destiny Fulfilled</i> era.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[353]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[354]</a></sup> The collection features sportswear, denim offerings with fur, outerwear and accessories that include handbags and footwear, and are available at department and specialty stores across the US and Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-BusWire_350-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BusWire-350">[349]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2005, Beyoncé teamed up with House of Brands, a shoe company, to produce a range of footwear for House of Deréon.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[355]</a></sup> In January 2008, Starwave Mobile launched Beyoncé Fashion Diva, a "high-style" <a href="/wiki/Mobile_game" title="Mobile game">mobile game</a> with a social networking component, featuring the House of Deréon collection.<sup id="cite_ref-BusWire_350-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BusWire-350">[349]</a></sup> In July 2009, Beyoncé and her mother launched a new junior apparel label, Sasha Fierce for Deréon, for back-to-school selling. The collection included sportswear, outerwear, handbags, footwear, eyewear, lingerie and jewelry.<sup id="cite_ref-Sasha_Fierce_clothing_line_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sasha_Fierce_clothing_line-357">[356]</a></sup> It was available at department stores including <a href="/wiki/Macy%27s" title="Macy's">Macy's</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dillard%27s" title="Dillard's">Dillard's</a>, and specialty stores Jimmy Jazz and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Against_All_Odds_(clothing_retailer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Against All Odds (clothing retailer) (page does not exist)">Against All Odds</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sasha_Fierce_clothing_line_357-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sasha_Fierce_clothing_line-357">[356]</a></sup> On May 27, 2010, Beyoncé teamed up with clothing store <a href="/wiki/C%26A" title="C&amp;A">C&amp;A</a> to launch Deréon by Beyoncé at their stores in Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-fashion_looks_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fashion_looks-358">[357]</a></sup> The collection included tailored blazers with padded shoulders, little black dresses, embroidered tops and shirts and bandage dresses.<sup id="cite_ref-fashion_looks_358-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fashion_looks-358">[357]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Philanthropy">Philanthropy</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beyonc%C3%A9_Cosmetology_Center.jpg" title="File:Beyoncé Cosmetology Center.jpg">File:Beyoncé Cosmetology Center.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Beyoncé (<i>center</i>) and her mother, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tina_Knowles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tina Knowles (page does not exist)">Tina</a>, (<i>left</i>) at the opening of the Beyoncé Cosmetology Center on March 5, 2010</div></div></div>
<p>After <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hurricane_Katrina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hurricane Katrina (page does not exist)">Hurricane Katrina</a> in 2005, Beyoncé and Rowland founded the Survivor Foundation to provide transitional housing for victims in the Houston area,<sup id="cite_ref-FOX_18-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOX-18">[18]</a></sup> to which Beyoncé contributed an initial $250,000.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[358]</a></sup> The foundation has since expanded to work with other charities in the city,<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[359]</a></sup> and also provided relief following <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hurricane_Ike&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hurricane Ike (page does not exist)">Hurricane Ike</a> three years later.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[360]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé participated in <a href="/wiki/George_Clooney" title="George Clooney">George Clooney</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wyclef_Jean" title="Wyclef Jean">Wyclef Jean</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hope_for_Haiti_Now:_A_Global_Benefit_for_Earthquake_Relief&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hope for Haiti Now: A Global Benefit for Earthquake Relief (page does not exist)">Hope for Haiti Now: A Global Benefit for Earthquake Relief</a> telethon<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[361]</a></sup> and was named the official face of the limited edition <a href="/w/index.php?title=Council_of_Fashion_Designers_of_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Council of Fashion Designers of America (page does not exist)">CFDA</a> "Fashion For Haiti" T-shirt,<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[362]</a></sup> made by <a href="/wiki/Theory" title="Theory">Theory</a> which raised a total of $1&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[363]</a></sup> On March 5, 2010, Beyoncé and her mother Tina opened the Beyoncé Cosmetology Center at the Brooklyn <a href="/w/index.php?title=Phoenix_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Phoenix House (page does not exist)">Phoenix House</a>, offering a seven-month <a href="/wiki/Cosmetology" title="Cosmetology">cosmetology</a> training course for men and women. <a href="/wiki/L%27Or%C3%A9al" title="L'Oréal">L'Oréal</a> donated all the products to be used at the center, and Beyoncé and Tina pledged to donate $100,000 annually.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[364]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyoncé became an ambassador for the 2012 <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Humanitarian_Day&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Humanitarian Day (page does not exist)">World Humanitarian Day</a> campaign donating her song "I Was Here" and its music video, shot in the UN, to the campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-WHD2012_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WHD2012-366">[365]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[366]</a></sup> On August 19, Beyoncé helped the campaign make social media history, having enlisted the help of other celebrities like Lady Gaga, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Justin_Bieber&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Justin Bieber (page does not exist)">Justin Bieber</a>, and Michelle Obama.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[367]</a></sup> as more than one billion messages were shared at the same time in relation to the event.<sup id="cite_ref-WHD2012_366-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WHD2012-366">[365]</a></sup> In 2013, it was announced that Beyoncé would work with <a href="/wiki/Salma_Hayek" title="Salma Hayek">Salma Hayek</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frida_Giannini&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frida Giannini (page does not exist)">Frida Giannini</a> on a <a href="/wiki/Gucci" title="Gucci">Gucci</a> "Chime for Change" campaign that aims to spread female empowerment. The campaign, which aired on February 28, was set to her new music.<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[368]</a></sup> A concert for the cause took place on June 1, 2013 in London<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[369]</a></sup> and included other acts like <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellie_Goulding&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ellie Goulding (page does not exist)">Ellie Goulding</a>, Florence and the Machine, and Rita Ora.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[370]</a></sup> Beyoncé is also taking part in "Miss a Meal", a food-donation campaign,<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[371]</a></sup> and supporting <a href="/wiki/Goodwill_Industries" title="Goodwill Industries">Goodwill charity</a> through online charity auctions at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charitybuzz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charitybuzz (page does not exist)">Charitybuzz</a> that support job creation throughout Europe and the U.S.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[372]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[373]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Discography">Discography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/Dangerously_in_Love" title="Dangerously in Love">Dangerously in Love</a></i> (2003)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=B%27Day&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="B'Day (page does not exist)">B'Day</a></i> (2006)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am..._Sasha_Fierce&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am... Sasha Fierce (page does not exist)">I Am... Sasha Fierce</a></i> (2008)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=4_(Beyonc%C3%A9_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="4 (Beyoncé album) (page does not exist)">4</a></i> (2011)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beyonc%C3%A9_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beyoncé (album) (page does not exist)">Beyoncé</a></i> (2013)
</li>
</ul>

film directors</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:African-American_film_producers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:African-American film producers (page does Methodists (page does not exist)">African-American Methodists</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:African-American_record_producers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new"
